title: First look at Britain's Greatest Hoaxer as prankster Simon Brodkin's seeks to 'expose' Britain's Got Talent
text:
First look at Britain's Greatest Hoaxer as prankster Simon Brodkin's seeks to 'expose' Britain's Got Talent These exclusive clips show the man behind Lee Nelson auditioning in front of the judges Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Infamous hoaxer Simon Brodkin sets his sights Britain's Got Talent Share this video   
This is the first look at prankster Simon Brodkin's controversial audition for Britain's Got Talent – when he claims contestants are manipulated to make good TV. 
Prankster Simon dressed up as an orthodox Jewish rapper and managed to get through to see the judges at auditions in January 2016. 
As part of his channel 4 documentary ‘Britain’s Greatest Hoaxer’ on Tuesday night , viewers will see him pose as rapper Steven Goldblatt which enables him to go backstage and secretly film his audition experience and see what really goes on. Simon auditioned as Steven Goldblatt (Photo: Channel 4) The rapper proved a hit with the judges (Photo: Channel 4) 
In his eight hours backstage, Brodkin told how producers coach and persuade contestants to say the right things to judges, manipulate what the acts do on stage and also film fake scenes of celebration and despair BEFORE people have even auditioned. Read More TV star Lee Nelson reveals how he's pranked everyone from Donald Trump to Kanye West and Simon Cowell 
Brodkin told Mirror Online: “This show sets itself up as a pure, simple, innocent talent show. In my opinion I don’t think it is that. It is contrived, manipulative and you don’t need to have talent. 
“Shortly before I went in front of the judges I was advised what to say and how to present my act. Read More Philip Green's yacht renamed BHS Destroyer by TV star Lee Nelson in political stunt “A lot is recreated and manipulated. My arrival, registration and leaving were all staged. I was given direction as to how to act and they reshot each stage several times. Once backstage they asked me to look nervous, happy, frustrated, excited etc, filming as many emotions as possible so they have the building blocks to build their own narrative.” Simon was contacted by producers with a questionnaire (Photo: Channel 4) He was invited to audition in front of the judges - and filmed it all (Photo: Channel 4) 
But a spokesman for the show hit back calling him a fame-hungry fraud and denied manipulation of acts.” 
In the documentary, Steven travels to Manchester for an initial audition with producers, without the judges present. 
He hides a camera in his beatbox stereo so he can film it. 
Brodkin said: “No suggestions were made on the day but four days ­afterwards I received a call from an ­associate producer who told me they liked my act but the rap I auditioned with was not right for the show. Read More Donald Trump's fury at Brit prankster hijacking his speech with Nazi golf balls in Scotland 
“They asked me for a new song, guiding me on what would work better for BGT.” 
After answering an 13-page questionnaire about himself he was called by production which, Brodkin says, was to “mine even more personal information and potential back stories”. The judges were impressed (Photo: Channel 4) He had to stay in character (Photo: Channel 4) 
The documentary then shows Brodkin having intensive ­make- up and prosthetics to pose as Steven before a London auditions for the BGT judges. 
Backstage footage shows him being repeatedly asked the same question to give the answer producers want. He is also seen posing with a flag, looking as if he is celebrating getting through. This footage is all filmed before he goes on stage. Read More Lee Nelson's craziest pranks: From storming the VW launch to almost ruining Kanye West’s Glastonbury set 
On stage Steven told the judges he cared for his dad after his mum died. He then raps about Britain, and why it is great, in the song Red, White and Blue. The judges are easily fooled and put him through to the next round with four yes votes. 
Cowell said after the audition: “That was great Steven, it makes you feel proud to be British, it could be like the new National Anthem. I wouldn’t have imagined, Steven, that coming from you. He claimed he was given directions (Photo: Channel 4) A BGT spokesman has denied manipulating contestants (Photo: Channel 4) 
“You are a quiet little thing. But then when the song started, you turned into like 50 Cent.” 
An executive producer then spotted he was Brodkin and he was stopped from going to the live shows and asked to leave. 
A BGT spokesman has said: “It is not unusual for Britain’s Got Talent to work with acts to ensure their performances are suitable for family viewing. 
“On this occasion Simon Brodkin ­auditioned with a rap containing material we were concerned may cause offence. Simon Brodkin has become infamous for his stunts (Photo: Evening Gazette) 
"We subsequently found out that Simon Brodkin is a ‘comedian’ and hoaxer who promotes his act by deceiving people. It is untrue to suggest that Britain’s Got Talent manipulated Simon’s act." 
A source added: “It’s ironic he thought it was funny to manipulate a full live theatre audience by making false claims about who he was and yet is trying to accuse Britain’s Got Talent of being manipulative. 
“This guy is just desperate for fame – and is hoping to get it by being a professional fraud and con artist.” 
* Britain’s Greatest Hoaxer, Channel 4 tonight at 10pm Like us on Facebook
